Posts.Content: whoopsiedoodles wrote: I got the scan results back (still not from the gallbladder/liver).  I have an 8mm enlarged lymph node.  PCP said to call some surgeon here in Indiana to biopsy it.  Of course, I did and they said they can get me in March 10th.  Of course, I said, "TO HELL WITH THAT."  I have been calling my oncologist at U of Chicago and her nurse assistant.  Neither one are available at my beck and call.  I am scared to death now.  WHAT THE HELL DO I DO NOW!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!   My son keeps saying, "Mommy, why are you crying."  I don't want to say that it's because I am scared the cancer is definitely back.  OH MY FREAKING GOD.  SOMEONE TELL ME WHAT THE HELL THIS ALL MEANS, PLEASE.  deb "And if it turns out it's over too fast, I'll make every last moment last" Dx 9/29/2005, IDC, 6cm+, Stage II, Grade 3, 0/7 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: OH MY FREAKING GOD!!! PART 2 HELP ME!!!!!!!! whoopsiedoodles JoyRebecca

Posts.Content: whoopsiedoodles wrote: I can't fall asleep because I am so worked up over this stupid test.  If I find out I have this awful mutation, it affects not only me, but my husband, son, brother, nieces and nephews.  I am worked up and freaked out that if I find out I have this stupid mutation........well, I will be constantly living as though I have cancer, even if there is nothing diagnosed in me at the moment.  I just want the 3 different tumors to have been a fluke.  A freak occurance.  The end of the cancer road for me.  I just want to live and enjoy my son, not spend my day feeling distracted and terrified and worried.    Cancer sucks so much.  Can you guys please do some of that elephant sister magic?  Love and prayers, Deb "And if it turns out it's over too fast, I'll make every last moment last" Dx 9/29/2005, IDC, 6cm+, Stage II, Grade 3, 0/7 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Li-Frauemeni Syndrome blood draw tomorrow! whoopsiedoodles susan_CNY

Posts.Content: whoopsiedoodles wrote: Count me in!  I freakin' LOVE this book and don't know why it's taken me so long to get it.  It's fantastic-I'd read her spread in Glamour and rip the pages out, but the book is FANTASTIC.  What a perfect depiction of life/love/cancer.  This is good if you are just dx'd, recently dx'd, dx'd years ago, or not dx'd at all.  "And if it turns out it's over too fast, I'll make every last moment last" Dx 9/29/2005, IDC, 6cm+, Stage II, Grade 3, 0/7 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: How many of you LOVE the book CANCER VIXEN? whoopsiedoodles NancyD

Posts.Content: whoopsiedoodles wrote: Robin Roberts announced on Good Morning America today that she does indeed have breast cancer. She said she discovered it the day they did the tribute to Joel Siegel after he died from cancer. My heart goes out to her. I remember all too well the terror of just being diagnosed. However, I am concerned about her because I (this is just my opinion) think she is trying to be the "strong one." She did admit that she will have bad days, but she and Diane Sawyer basically said this is just going to be a bump in the road. That also concerns me because what about our future sisters who just get diagnosed? What is that going to lead them to think about the road that lies ahead? Those of us further along in our journey KNOW that cancer will never just be a bump in the road. Once it becomes a part of our lives, it is going to stay a part of us and who we are. What do you all think? I am curious and will be posting this on other boards too. Love and prayers, Deb "And if it turns out it's over too fast, I'll make every last moment last" Dx 9/29/2005, IDC, 6cm+, Stage II, Grade 3, 0/7 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Robin Roberts on GMA is in our club whoopsiedoodles whoopsiedoodles

Posts.Content: whoopsiedoodles wrote: I didn't realize it until late last night that it has now officially been two years since I lost my "girls."  Oh, how far I've come since then.  Clothes fit different.  Very different.  I'm not afraid to show people my foobs.  I will tell anyone who asks about what cancer is like.  Don't get me wrong.  I miss my breasts so very much (just read the mojo thread).  They were a HUGE part of me (no pun intended, since I had DD's).  They fed my baby.  BUT.....I tell people all the time that if I needed to have my LEGS removed so I could watch my son grow older, I would.  That goal was reached this past week!  I celebrated my baby's 4th birthday.  He was 18 months when I was diagnosed!  Yes, I miss my breasts, but I praise the LORD that I am still here today.   Thanks, sisters, for getting me through the hardest time of my life!  Love and prayers, Deb "And if it turns out it's over too fast, I'll make every last moment last" Dx 9/29/2005, IDC, 6cm+, Stage II, Grade 3, 0/7 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Yesterday was my 2 year Mastect-a-versary!! whoopsiedoodles lvtwoqlt

Posts.Content: whoopsiedoodles wrote: Ladies, I'm sitting at my oncologist's office trying to find an answer as to why I keep getting cancer.  She is very confident that it is P53/Li-Fraumeni Syndrome, which of course is so rare only 400 or so cases are documented a year!  BAH!  So, I will be getting a tube of blood drawn right away for the BART (?) test, which I guess didn't exist when I did genetic testing in 2005.  I have to get a preauthorization and come back to do the P53 test, which is freaking expensive.  Boy, does that syndrome sound fun.  Elephants?  Anyone there? "And if it turns out it's over too fast, I'll make every last moment last" Dx 9/29/2005, IDC, 6cm+, Stage II, Grade 3, 0/7 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Li-Frauemeni Syndrome whoopsiedoodles Sydney6

Posts.Content: whoopsiedoodles wrote: Just seeking experienced thoughts because I am worried as usual... What is up with this sudden pain?  I didn't even notice it until I brushed against it with my hand the other day.  It is right under my right temple, literally on the hinge of my jaw.  It only hurts if I press at it.  My hubby's response to that, of course, is, "Don't press it...."  It is tender to the touch, and very, VERY localized.  What the heck could this be, because I of course have self-diagnosed myself and googled it.  Any thoughts?  I love you ladies!  Love and prayers, Deb "And if it turns out it's over too fast, I'll make every last moment last" Dx 9/29/2005, IDC, 6cm+, Stage II, Grade 3, 0/7 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: I have a pain on my jaw hinge?! whoopsiedoodles whoopsiedoodles
